title: 104_s270
content: The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" allows for the removal of alien terrorists under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" defines key terms and procedures for the removal of alien terrorists, including the use of classified information and special removal hearings. The Attorney General must certify the presence of an alien terrorist in the US for deportation. The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" allows for the removal of alien terrorists through deportation proceedings that may involve classified information. A special court with designated judges hears and decides cases related to this act, following procedures similar to those in the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. When the Attorney General applies for deportation, a single judge considers the application in camera and ex parte. The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" allows for the removal of alien terrorists through deportation proceedings that may involve classified information. A special removal hearing is conducted if there is probable cause to believe the identified alien poses a national security risk and immediate physical harm. The hearing is open to the public, and the alien has the right to be present and represented by counsel. The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" allows for the removal of alien terrorists through deportation proceedings. If unable to obtain counsel, the alien is entitled to have counsel assigned. The alien has the right to introduce evidence, cross-examine witnesses, and request subpoenas. The judge can authorize the introduction of classified evidence in camera. The judge must provide the alien with a substitution or summary of classified evidence. The judge can authorize the introduction of classified evidence in camera and must provide the alien with a substitution or summary of classified evidence if disclosure poses a risk of harm. The judge can order deportation of an alien if the Attorney General proves by clear and convincing evidence that the alien is subject to deportation. Appeals can be made to the court of appeals for the Federal Circuit within twenty days of the determination. The court of appeals for the Federal Circuit can consider appeals in camera and ex parte when requested by the Attorney General, with the entire record of the proceeding transmitted under seal.
